question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
To compute the coefficient, start with

\[\begin{aligned} f(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }c_ne_n(t)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\displaystyle f(t)=t^2-t\) and \(\displaystyle e_n(t)=e^{2\pi int}\). Also, we have L=1-0=1. Take the inner product of \(f\)(t) with \(e_m\). The only term in the infinite sum that remains is the one with \(n=m\), and in this case \(\langle e_n, e_n\rangle = 1\). Thus

\[\begin{aligned} \left \langle f,e_m \right \rangle=\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }c_n\left \langle e_n,e_m \right \rangle=c_m\end{aligned}\]

and we get the formula

\[\begin{aligned} c_m = \langle f,e_m \rangle = \int_{0}^{1} f(t) e^{-2\pi imt}\,dt=\int_{0}^{1}f(t)\overline{g(t)}\,dt\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle \overline{g(t)}=e^{-2\pi imt}\) we have \(\displaystyle g(t)=e^{2\pi imt}\), and so we overall find that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle c_n = \langle t^2-t, e^{2\pi int} \rangle\end{aligned}\]
